unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Graphing Check
question_text:
A nutritionist was interested in the average amount of water a person drinks per day.
She interviewed $20$ randomly chosen subjects and found that they drink an average of $33.1$ ounces of water per day with a standard deviation of $7.4$ ounces.
In this situation, under what conditions could the nutritionist perform a one-sample T-test or one-sample T-interval?

choices.text: If the data graphed of the $20$ subjects shows perfect normality, she could perform a one-sample T-test or one-sample T-interval.
If the data graphed of the $20$ subjects shows perfect normality, she could perform a one-sample T-test; however, a one-sample T-interval would still be inappropriate in this situation.
If the data graphed of the $20$ subjects shows approximate normality, she could perform a one-sample T-test or one-sample T-interval.
As long as the graph of the $20$ subjects shows no outliers and no strong skewness, T procedures such as a one-sample T-test and one-sample T-interval are safe to use here.
For a sample size of n = $20$, she can perform a one-sample T-test or one-sample T-interval regardless of how the sample looks when graphed.

solution:
For sample sizes of approximately $10$ to $30$, the sampling distribution will be roughly normal as long as the data graphed shows no strong skewness or outliers.

Keep in mind, however, that sampling distributions gradually look closer to normal as sample size increases, and $10$ and $30$ are not strict cutoffs.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'D'.
